latestVersion.citationRequirements: International Food Policy Research Institute (IFPRI). 2014. Farmer's Preferences for Abiotic Stress Tolerance in Hybrid versus Traditional Rice: Evidence from Bihar, India (2012-13). Washington, DC: International Food Policy Research Institute (IFPRI) [dataset]. http://dx.doi.org/10.7910/DVN/26930
latestVersion.disclaimer:
IFPRI adheres to the principle of unrestricted public access to its own final research outputs and will make such outputs freely available. The Institute encourages the use of the Farmer's Preferences for Abiotic Stress Tolerance in Hybrid versus Traditional Rice: Evidence from Bihar, India (2012-13) dataset; for detailed information on its use, please refer to IFPRI’s Intellectual Property Policy. The data files in these datasets are unit record or ‘raw’ data files. Information that would allow survey respondents to be identified has been deleted from the files, but all other information remains. IFPRI’s decision not to alter the contents of the data files means that the user of these files will need to take care in handling missing observations, outliers, and violations of logical consistency.

The data are provided ‘as is’ and in no event shall IFPRI be liable for any damages resulting from the use of the data. While great effort was taken to obtain high-quality data, the accuracy or reliability of the data is not guaranteed or warranted in any way.

fields.value: Farmer's Preferences for Abiotic Stress Tolerance in Hybrid versus Traditional Rice: Evidence from Bihar, India (2012-13)

dsDescriptionValue.value: The survey,Farmer's Preferences for Abiotic Stress Tolerance in Hybrid versus Traditional Rice: Evidence from Bihar, India (2012-13), was designed to assess farmer's willingness to pay for drought-tolerant paddy in Bihar, India. The survey includes carefully designed discrete choice experiments and a risk experiment to collect information on demand for drought tolerance characteristics in rice and the role of both the public and the private sector in the research and development of the same. The data were collected from 576 rice-producing households in rural Bihar, as a part of a study under the Cereal Systems Initiative for South Asia (CSISA).CSISA's vision is to decrease hunger and malnutrition and to increase food and income security for resource-poor farm households in Bangladesh, India, and Nepal through the accelerated development and inclusive deployment of new and improved crop varieties, sustainable technologies and management practices, and improved policies.

value: Ward, Patrick S.; Ortega, David L.; Spielman, David J.; and Singh, Vartika. 2014. Heterogeneous demand for drought-tolerant rice: Evidence from Bihar, India. World Development 64 (December 2014): 125-139.http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.worlddev.2014.05.017

Ward, Patrick S.; Ortega, David L.; Spielman, David J.; and Singh, Vartika. 2013. Farmer Preferences for Abiotic Stress Tolerance in Hybrid versus Inbred Rice: Evidence from Bihar, India. Selected Paper prepared for presentation at the Agricultural and Applied Economics Association 2013 AAEA & CAES Joint Annual Meeting, Washington, D.C., August 4-6, 2013.

Ward, Patrick S.; and Singh, Vartika. 2013. Risk and Ambiguity Preferences and the Adoption of New Agricultural Technologies: Evidence from Field Experiments in Rural India. Selected Paper prepared for presentation at the Agricultural and Applied Economics Association 2013 AAEA & CAES Joint Annual Meeting, Washington, D.C., August 4-6, 2013.

Ward, Patrick S.; Ortega, David L.; Spielman, David J. and Singh, Vartika. 2013. Farmer preferences for drought tolerance in hybrid versus inbred rice: Evidence from Bihar, India. IFPRI Discussion Paper 1307. Washington, DC: International Food Policy Research Institute (IFPRI). http://ebrary.ifpri.org/cdm/ref/collection/p15738coll2/id/127956

Ward, Patrick S.; and Singh, Vartika. 2014. Risk and ambiguity preferences and the adoption of new agricultural technologies: Evidence from field experiments in rural India. IFPRI Discussion Paper 1324. Washington, DC: International Food Policy Research Institute (IFPRI). http://ebrary.ifpri.org/cdm/ref/collection/p15738coll2/id/128016
Rice growing households in rural areas of Bihar, India

fields.value: This survey was conducted by enumerators under the supervision of researchers from IFPRI and field supervision and management staff of New Concept Information Systems Pvt. Ltd.

The sample consists of 576 rice-producing households in rural Bihar state based on a multi-stage sampling approach. In the first stage, three districts were selected that are heavily dependent upon rice production: Bhojpur, Madhubani, and Nawada. In the second stage, 16 high rice-producing blocks (sub-district administrative units) were selected across the three districts. The number of blocks drawn from each district is proportional to the share of rice production attributable to each district. Seven blocks were selected from Bhojpur, three from Nawada, and six from Madhubani. Within each of these blocks, two villages were randomly selected from which to draw households. From each of these villages, 18 rice-growing households were randomly selected from village rosters prepared by enumerators through door-to-door listing. And, from each household, the head male and head female were interviewed. Thus our total sample comprises of 576 households, with some modules being addressed only to men, some modules addressed only to women, and some modules addressed to both men and women.
